an7.76:0.3.eng: An Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)

an7.76:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti.
an7.76:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.

an7.76:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.76:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.76:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.76:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.76:1.7.pli: ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso,
an7.76:1.7.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an7.76:1.8.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an7.76:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an7.76:1.9.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.76:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.76:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hotī”ti.
an7.76:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.77:0.3.eng: An Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)

an7.77:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti.
an7.77:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.

an7.77:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.77:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.77:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.77:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.77:1.7.pli: vinaye kho pana ṭhito hoti asaṃhīro,
an7.77:1.7.eng: They’re firm and unfaltering in the training.

an7.77:1.8.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an7.77:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an7.77:1.9.pli: āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.77:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.77:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hotī”ti.
an7.77:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.78:0.3.eng: An Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)

an7.78:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti.
an7.78:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.

an7.78:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.78:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.78:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.78:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.78:1.7.pli: anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
an7.78:1.7.eng: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an7.78:1.8.pli: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
an7.78:1.8.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an7.78:1.9.pli: Āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.78:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.78:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hotī”ti.
an7.78:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities is an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.79:0.3.eng: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (1st)

an7.79:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.

an7.79:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.79:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.79:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.79:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.79:1.7.eng: They’re ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places; seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an7.79:1.8.pli: catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī,
an7.79:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an7.79:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.79:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato vinayadharo sobhatī”ti.
an7.79:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.8:1.3.pli: Anunayasaṃyojanaṃ, paṭighasaṃyojanaṃ, diṭṭhisaṃyojanaṃ, vicikicchāsaṃyojanaṃ, mānasaṃyojanaṃ, bhavarāgasaṃyojanaṃ, avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ.
an7.8:1.3.eng: The fetters of attraction, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

an7.80:0.3.eng: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (2nd)

an7.80:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.

an7.80:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.80:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.80:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.80:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.80:1.7.pli: ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso,
an7.80:1.7.eng: Both monastic codes have been passed down to them in detail, well analyzed, well mastered, well evaluated in both the rules and accompanying material.

an7.80:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an7.80:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.80:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato vinayadharo sobhatī”ti.
an7.80:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.81:0.3.eng: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (3rd)

an7.81:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.

an7.81:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.81:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.81:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.81:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.81:1.7.pli: vinaye kho pana ṭhito hoti asaṃhīro,
an7.81:1.7.eng: They’re firm and unfaltering in the training.

an7.81:1.8.eng: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.

an7.81:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.81:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato vinayadharo sobhatī”ti.
an7.81:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.82:0.3.eng: Shines as an Expert in the Monastic Law (4th)

an7.82:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.

an7.82:1.3.eng: They know what is an offense.

an7.82:1.4.eng: They know what is not an offense.

an7.82:1.5.eng: They know what is a light offense.

an7.82:1.6.eng: They know what is a serious offense.

an7.82:1.7.pli: anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati,
an7.82:1.7.eng: They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

an7.82:1.8.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

an7.82:1.9.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.82:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato vinayadharo sobhatī”ti.
an7.82:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities shines as an expert in the monastic law.”

an7.83:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upāli yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā upāli bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.83:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Upāli went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an7.83:2.1.pli: “Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
an7.83:2.1.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

an7.83:2.3.pli: ‘ime dhammā na ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattantī’ti;
an7.83:2.3.eng: certain things don’t lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

an7.83:2.4.eng: Categorically, you should remember these things as

an7.83:2.5.eng: not the teaching, not the training, and not the Teacher’s instructions.

an7.83:2.6.pli: Ye ca kho tvaṃ, upāli, dhamme jāneyyāsi:

an7.83:2.7.pli: ‘ime dhammā ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattantī’ti;
an7.83:2.7.eng: certain things do lead solely to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

an7.83:2.8.eng: Categorically, you should remember these things as

an7.83:2.9.eng: the teaching, the training, and the Teacher’s instructions.”

an7.84:1.1.pli: “Sattime, bhikkhave, adhikaraṇasamathā dhammā uppannuppannānaṃ adhikaraṇānaṃ samathāya vūpasamāya.
an7.84:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven principles for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.

an7.84:1.3.pli: Sammukhāvinayo dātabbo, sativinayo dātabbo, amūḷhavinayo dātabbo, paṭiññātakaraṇaṃ dātabbaṃ, yebhuyyasikā dātabbā, tassapāpiyasikā dātabbā, tiṇavatthārako dātabbo.
an7.84:1.3.eng: Resolution face-to-face to be applied. Resolution through recollection to be granted. Resolution because of past insanity to be granted. Acting according to what has been admitted. Majority decision. Further penalty. Covering over as if with grass.

an7.84:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta adhikaraṇasamathā dhammā uppannuppannānaṃ adhikaraṇānaṃ samathāya vūpasamāyā”ti.
an7.84:1.4.eng: These are the seven principles for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.”

an7.85:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of breaking seven things that you become a mendicant.

an7.85:1.3.pli: Sakkāyadiṭṭhi bhinnā hoti, vicikicchā bhinnā hoti, sīlabbataparāmāso bhinno hoti, rāgo bhinno hoti, doso bhinno hoti, moho bhinno hoti, māno bhinno hoti.
an7.85:1.3.eng: Substantialist view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, greed, hate, delusion, and conceit.

an7.85:1.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sattannaṃ dhammānaṃ bhinnattā bhikkhu hotī”ti.
an7.85:1.4.eng: It’s because of breaking these seven things that you become a mendicant.”

an7.86:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of quelling seven things that you become an ascetic …”

an7.87:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of barring out seven things that you become a brahmin …”

an7.88:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of scouring off seven things that you become a scholar …”

an7.89:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of bathing off seven things that you become a bathed initiate …”

an7.9:1.1.pli: “Sattannaṃ, bhikkhave, saṃyojanānaṃ pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
an7.9:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the spiritual life is lived to give up and cut out these seven fetters.

an7.9:1.3.pli: Anunayasaṃyojanassa pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati, paṭighasaṃyojanassa …pe…
an7.9:1.3.eng: The fetters of attraction, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

an7.9:1.9.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sattannaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ pahānāya samucchedāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
an7.9:1.9.eng: The spiritual life is lived to give up and cut out these seven fetters.

an7.9:1.10.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno anunayasaṃyojanaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
an7.9:1.10.eng: When a mendicant has given up the fetters of attraction, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance—cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future—

an7.9:1.16.pli: avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.

an7.9:1.17.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”ti.
an7.9:1.17.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”

an7.90:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because of knowing seven things that you become a knowledge master …”

an7.91:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s because seven foes have been nobbled that you become a noble one …”

an7.92:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it’s by being impeccably remote from seven things that you become a perfected one.

an7.92:1.3.pli: Sakkāyadiṭṭhi ārakā hoti, vicikicchā ārakā hoti, sīlabbataparāmāso ārako hoti, rāgo ārako hoti, doso ārako hoti, moho ārako hoti, māno ārako hoti.
an7.92:1.3.eng: Substantialist view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, greed, hate, delusion, and conceit.

an7.92:1.4.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sattannaṃ dhammānaṃ ārakattā arahā hotī”ti.
an7.92:1.4.eng: It’s because of being impeccably remote from these seven things that you become a perfected one.”

an7.93:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven bad qualities.

an7.93:1.3.pli: Assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
an7.93:1.3.eng: Someone is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.

an7.93:1.4.eng: These are the seven bad qualities.”

an7.94:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven good qualities.

an7.94:1.3.pli: Saddho hoti, hirīmā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, satimā hoti, paññavā hoti.
an7.94:1.3.eng: Someone is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

an7.94:1.4.eng: These are the seven good qualities.”

an7.95:1.1.pli: “Sattime, bhikkhave, puggalā āhuneyyā …pe… dakkhiṇeyyā añjalikaraṇīyā anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an7.95:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these seven individuals are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.

an7.95:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo cakkhusmiṃ aniccānupassī viharati aniccasaññī aniccapaṭisaṃvedī satataṃ samitaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ cetasā adhimuccamāno paññāya pariyogāhamāno.
an7.95:1.3.eng: First, take an individual who meditates observing impermanence in the eye. They perceive impermanence and experience impermanence. Constantly, continually, and without interruption, they apply the mind and fathom with wisdom.

an7.95:1.4.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.95:1.4.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.95:1.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, paṭhamo puggalo āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an7.95:1.5.eng: This is the first individual who is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an7.95:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo cakkhusmiṃ aniccānupassī viharati aniccasaññī aniccapaṭisaṃvedī satataṃ samitaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ cetasā adhimuccamāno paññāya pariyogāhamāno.
an7.95:2.1.eng: Next, take an individual who meditates observing impermanence in the eye. …

an7.95:2.2.pli: Tassa apubbaṃ acarimaṃ āsavapariyādānañca hoti jīvitapariyādānañca.
an7.95:2.2.eng: Their defilements and their life come to an end at exactly the same time.

an7.95:2.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo puggalo āhuneyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an7.95:2.3.eng: This is the second individual who is worthy of offerings …

an7.95:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo cakkhusmiṃ aniccānupassī viharati aniccasaññī aniccapaṭisaṃvedī satataṃ samitaṃ abbokiṇṇaṃ cetasā adhimuccamāno paññāya pariyogāhamāno.
an7.95:3.1.eng: Next, take an individual who meditates observing impermanence in the eye. …

an7.95:3.2.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti …pe…
an7.95:3.2.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished between one life and the next. …

an7.95:3.3.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished upon landing. …

an7.95:3.4.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort. …

an7.95:3.5.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort. …

an7.95:3.6.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm. …

an7.95:3.7.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, sattamo puggalo āhuneyyo …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.

an7.95:3.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta puggalā āhuneyyā pāhuneyyā dakkhiṇeyyā añjalikaraṇīyā anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an7.95:3.8.eng: These are the seven individuals who are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.”
